conclusion: To determine how the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time changes from state C to state D in the Stirling cycle, we need to analyze the isothermal process Câ†’D.
The transition from state C to state D is an isothermal process, meaning the temperature remains constant throughout this transition.

For an ideal gas undergoing an isothermal process, the relationship between pressure (P), volume (V), and temperature (T) is given by the ideal gas law: PV = nRT, where n is the number of moles and R is the ideal gas constant.

premise: Since the temperature is constant, PV remains constant.
conclusion: In the P-V diagram, as the gas transitions from state C to state D, the volume increases while the pressure decreases.
The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time is related to the pressure exerted by the gas.
Pressure is a measure of the force exerted by gas molecules colliding with the walls of the container.

premise: From state C to state D, the pressure decreases as the volume increases.
conclusion: As the pressure decreases, the frequency of molecular collisions with the wall decreases.

premise: Pressure is directly proportional to the number of collisions per unit area per unit time.
conclusion: Therefore, from state C to state D, the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time decreases.
